text: 1. My speech rests in the mind, my mind rests in speech 3 . Appear to me (thou, the Highest Self)! You (speech and mind) are the two pins 4 (that hold the wheels) of the Veda. May what I have learnt not forsake me 5 . I join day and night with what I have learnt 6 . I shall speak of the real, I shall speak the true. May this protect me, may this protect the teacher! May it protect me, may it protect the teacher, yea, the teacher!

text: 246:2 This seventh adhyâya contains a propitiatory prayer ( s ântikaro mantra h ). It is frequently left out in the MSS. which contain the Aitareya-upanishad with S aṅkara's commentary, and Dr. Roer has omitted it in his edition. Sâya n a explains it in his commentary on the Aitareya-âranyaka; and in one MS. of S aṅkara's commentary on the Aitareya-upanishad, which is in my possession, the seventh adhyâya is added with the commentary of Mâdhavâmâtya, the Â g ñâpâlaka of Vîrabukka-mahârâ g a.
